title: Differences between Indian and American secularism? - Quora

response.answer_text: When we tend to draw comparison between Indian and American Secularism ,it is first important to understand that the term secular is only common while the traits which reflect the type of culture that exists is quite different. So, what exactly is American Secularism, well that has its genesis not only in the American Constitution but in the American way of life. USA represents the complete separation of sacred and secular. They have a meritocratic society. They place very little value to the religious identity of the people who live there. It is complete separation of people's religious identity from that of their public identity and this domain is kept completely insulated from getting affected by religious identity.this is one of the paradigm of American dream which people have sought for atleast since many decades. Indian secularism on the other hand originated out of the Indian constitution and she declared herself as such only in the Preamble and that too after 42nd Amendment of 1976,other than that India has formally not declared itself as secular.Although,Owing to India's diversity India is indeed secular country with equidistant secularism wherein equal recognition is given to each and every religion and religious identities are not shun away. reservations are given to minority on the basis of religion and subsidies for visiting Haj or Kailash Mansarovar is also given.So, India tries to draw a subtle balance among all the religious identities along with political appeasement of religious identities. In India, religious identities are not at all dismissed at one place and people do have freedom to express their religious identity and embrace them even pubicly.Although ,this ensures freedom of expression but at times encroaches upon the discipline of the public life as various identities might cause a clash.Apart from that, it is also important to highlight that Indian Society is highly religious while the constitution tries to draw a subtle balance that many a times goes out of its hand owing to existing different political parties in power who more often than not Color the policies according to their ideology and preferences.but neither of the society ,be it American nor Indian society can be thought to be completely secular owing to its own set of flaws.American society is no longer a secular society owing to its biasness against Islam post 9/11 and it's phobia towards a particular religion.the particular incident continue to guide their immigration policy to foreign policies and thus American society is not completely secular while India has her own set of benefits and flaws that she gives freedom of expression to the people and respects diversity but it also gives rise to few of the hortible violence pasts like Babri Masjid demolition, Gujarat riots to name a few.

Ok. This answer is surely going to offend pseudo seculars. And if I hurt their sentiments, they need to watch out what is wrong from their side. Because what I am speaking is hard truth. In US, where the majority is christian, if you make fun of jesus in public, the reaction of the people will be either :1) they will laugh along with you and enjoy the joke or 2) they will simply walk away, giving zero fucks. While in India, making jokes on religious problems means that you have successfully triggered a lots of people. Just 2 days back, I posted a self-made meme based on the radical islamic terrorrism in a closed group of facebook. And yesterday only, two people reached in my messanger inbox, abusing me and even giving me death threats. I just want to say that, if you mock every other religion, you should have enough tolerance to mock your own, too. I have made dozens of memes on wrong/inappropriate hindu rituals. But no one gave a damn. This is secularism. Take jokes as jokes, be mature enough. Are allah/bhagwan/christ a two years old toddler that their feelings will get hurt on literally anything? They are gods, far more mature than all of us combined. They can take the jokes.In the US, bashing christianity(majority) is not a trend, or a way to get instant fame. Nobody shows off their religious beliefs. If you consider shiv as the only one, worship him. If he is allah for someone else, let him worship him, and for a christian, let him worship jesus. Why to show off your personal choice in public? But here, in India, by bashing hinduism(majority) every now and then will reward you with a label of secular and you will rise to instant fame.In the US, killing of mexican trespassers who try to invade through borders does not get a name of ‘christian terrorrism’. But here, in India, killing the jihadi trespassers, and illegal rohingya invaders will surely be coined as ‘hindu terrorrism/saffron terrorrism’.In the US, no one fears approaching for the minorities. Here, in India, some extreme hinduists and conservative hindus will still not be able to befriend the minorities. Yes, this is the problem with some of the hindus.In the US, there is no restriction or social shame in exploring the other religions. But saddeningly enough, in India, the society will kill you if you try to learn something about a religion which is not yours.But, still, India has sustained, right? Because the majority of us have literally no radical or extremist approach. There are a very few who try to break us. But unfortunately for us, most of the pseudo-seculars possess a blue tick besides their twitter accounts. And we people get influenced by them only. We have so much love and respect for each other at the core of our hearts, but the venom spread by the dirty politicians and radicals has coated it with a film of hatred. Let us wash it out, and be one. Respecting each other is what secularism means. And we Indians excell at respecting a person. Peace!

The word secular is used to separate state from the religion. The church started interfering in the affairs of state in many countries. To separate the church from the administration of state, the concept of secularism was started in west. In some countries laws are made to separate the role of church and the state in the administration of states. Initially the Church opposed the new system. But when democracy took root in western countries, the church separated its activities from administration. The church confined to religion, prayer, baptism, education and health care in remote areas. When USA is formed the concept of secularism took a new turn. The administration in USA adopted a principle to non interference in any religious activities of any community. The state became non religious in its approach. It continued its approach to religion till date. But the elected representatives, Governors, President and Vice President , take oath in the name of God. The state never give any grant to the church or any other religious institutes. But in India the concept of secularism is different from the west. In India secularism is started with adoption of the constitution. No religion is encouraged by state in India. No grant or assistance is granted to any religion in India. Conversion is banned in many states. Conversion is discouraged by the state. Religious institutes are allowed to have schools, colleges and hospitals. But slowly some political parties started the concept of anti hinduism concept as secular. But slowly the concept of anti hinduism may die down. Hindu religion is the most secular religion of the world. It never tried to make conversion even in the past. The concept of Hindu Sanatana Dharma is divine and eternal.

Secularism as a concept grown in west and the world fallowed it with some changes best suited for their society. like way India has taken secularism of Indian type. Secularism of America promote complete separation & non interference of church in government visa versa.That means government has nothing to do with religion & religion has nothing to do with government. where as Indian secularism has different connotation where government do not fallow any particular religion and also do not appease any single religion. But government is free to take steps which may seems to be interference in religious matter, in order for betterment of classes in particular & society as a whole. e.g laws against dowry, opening up of temples for all section of society & many more. Also Indian secularism emphasis on promotion to all & appeasement to none which is not there in American secularism. e.g Indian government recognizes waqf board and also approves grants.

we are not secular , we never were . why do you think we are, where did you see that written, are you another one of those people who got misguided by the preamble , that says India is a secular nation, people can be secular but nation such as India can not be, in United States they fought a 4 year long war and 400 years of struggle to get out of the blemish of slavery but in India with a stock of pen we on first page wrote that we are secular awesome fun loving democratic country which we were not and still we are not. and reason for that is simple we never knew a lack of the provisions that we have in our constitution today so realising the importance of them without any struggle can never be effective in its true sense. we are now fighting for LOKPAL for some time now and when whole country will stand and fight for it they will have to pass that bill and then in future we will cherish the idea of lokpal and we will probable never question the lokpal because it was based on struggle of generations. so please before asking question just take a look at the picture don't just throw around words like secular and India in the same breath. writing shit on paper doesn't make it happen, even if that paper is our constitution.

The primary difference between the American and Indian secularism is that in the American secularism, the state does not intervene in religious affairs, but in the Indian secularism, the state can intervene and it often does. For example, the Indian state has facilitated the entry of socially underprivileged into temples, but if such a situation is to arise there in America, the state will not intervene as religion affairs are independent of the state’s intervention. Source: This answer is based on what I studied in school.

The US and India have identified as ‘secular’ in their constitution. While the US recognizes no religion as part of their secularism, India accepts all religions as part of their secular fabric. US does not hinder the operations of any religion. India, on the other hand, tries to define the operational territories of each and every religion. For example, altercations between religions is a cour/constitution matter in the US. In India, it will be channelled through dirty political pipes before it even becomes a public debate. That is the difference between Indian secularism and the US secularism.

Secularism as put by George Holyoake is a concept of establishing an order where religion and politics (State) should be separated. Hence western societies believe in this type of secularism which may be called Hard Secularism (by Barry Kosmin). So it is in the US too. However, in a country like our’s which is diverse in diversities need to have tolerance at its core. Hence the framers of the constitution have incorporated the principle of religious tolerance on which our secularism is founded. The state generally does not intervene in religious doctrines but it may impose restrictions on religious freedom on the grounds of health, morality or public order and it may also by law regulate all secular activities.
The differences between Indian secularism and American Secularism are summarized in the following table. I hope it will clarify the differences.  (Image source: Phone's gallery)

US is a Christan country which accommodates other religions, but primacy remains with Christianty. If you take an ethnic view, the settlers white Americans who migrated from Europe call the shots. Secularism as a concept was relevant to Christian countries as it meant separation of Church from State. In India, traditionally Dharma was overriding concept. From King to artisan, everybody has his or her own Dharma to follow. In India, there was no Church to say everything goes around Earth or world started in 4500 BC, scientists either accept or die. There was no need to introduce secularism in Indian constitution. Secularism the way it got implemented made religion, caste and sect as political constructs that perpetuated divisions. Hinduism not only lost primacy became vulnerable to conversion, violence and divisions in the name of caste and class giving asymmetric disadvantage to Hindus.

Secularism in Indian constitution meant for no discrimination among religious communities for various proposes or schemes, implying equal respect and treatment to every faith. Whereas in European/American countries, churches had too much influence in the activities of government and policy making, so their concept of secularism means that no interference or lobbying by churches or any religious institutes.

In India, a very broad set of heterogeneous people and groups call themselves secular each with different agendas, but they all really have only one thing in common. They fear a united, caste-free, Hinduism-aligned society , and its implications. All talk of secularism is really about going to any lengths to prevent this from happening. In the US, secularism is about ‘separation of the church from the state’, i.e US Congress will not make laws that favour one religion over another.

Secularism is of two dimensions PositiveNegativePositive dimension of Secularism is when state accepts all religions as equal and provides equal status in opportunity and priority Ex: Indian Secularism Negative dimension of Secularism is when state distants itself from the religion. It doesn't promote any religion. Ex: US Secularism

American Secularism:  It runs 24x7x365 across 50 states. Indian Secularism:    It depends. Unlike, Modi who only feeds off majority and only celebrates Diwali with Army men.

Secularism means that state(here state means nation) will not promote any religion. The primary difference between the American and Indian secularism is that in the American secularism, the state does not intervene in religious affairs, but in the Indian secularism, the state can intervene and it often does. Ref: Google

Secularism means that state(here state means nation) will not promote any religion. In US if any religious community wants to build any religious site and they go to the government , the government will not support them in any means. The government cannot support or oppose any religious community. Whereas in india the state will help the religious community in building the religious site.
Indian secularism is fake and anti-Hindu, American secularism separates all religions from the government. No majority or minority based on religion.

American secularism : State and religion are two different subjects. They shouldn't be intermixed. Indian secularism : Equal treatment to all religions, state can't discriminate someone on the basis of religion.

American secularism entails a complete separation of Church and state. This is not possible in a deeply religious and spiritual society like India. Therefore Indian secularism is more about non promotion of one religion or sect by the govt. over another. Which is why in India we had until very recently a Hajj Subsidy for Muslims and Kailash Mansarovar Yatra for Hindus.

There is only one secularism. It is separation of religion from governance. There are versions. It is not nation-specific. It is not religion-specific. Those who tell you about versions are pseudo seculars.
Indian secularism is closer to the ideals the CSA stood for, notwithstanding slavery.
